posts._title: Robert Bresson – Journal d’un curé de campagne aka Diary of a Country Priest [+ commentary] (1951)
posts.title: Journal d’un curé de campagne
posts.excerpt: Quote:A new priest (Claude Laydu) arrives in the French country village of Ambricourt to attend to his first parish. The apathetic and hostile rural congregation rejects him immediately. Through his diary entries, the suffering young man relays a crisis of faith that threatens to drive him away from the village and from God. With his …
posts.titleEnglish: Diary of a Country Priest [+ commentary]

posts.title: Smeker
posts.excerpt: Quote:The story of a young man from the suburb, who gets his experience on the street and in bars. His girlfriend belongs to the same environment. When he goes to army, she tries to get away, giving the only thing she has – her good looks. She poses nude for some magazine. Seeing that photo, …

posts._title: Kamen Kalev – Iztochni piesi AKA Eastern Plays (2009)
posts.title: Iztochni piesi
posts.excerpt: Quote:Two brothers who have lost all contact are suddenly brought together when they have opposite roles in a racist beating: while Georgi who’s recently joined a neonazi group participates in the violence, Itso witnesses and rescues the Turkish family. Georgi, now being asked to participate in larger events, starts to question his implication in the …

posts._title: Alberto Lattuada – Il bandito AKA The Bandit (1946)
posts.title: Il bandito
posts.excerpt: A contingent of Italian prisoners of war arrive on a train from Germany after World War II to Turin. The city where Ernesto lives has been bombed, his mother is dead and his sister has gone missing.

posts.title: Black Shampoo
posts.excerpt: A black hairstylist has sex with his female customers, and tries to keep the Mafia from taking over his business.

posts.title: Gau ngao gau
posts.excerpt: Plot Synopsis from beyondhollywood.comAlthough many Hong Kong thrillers like to style themselves as being gritty and nihilistic, “Dog Bite Dog” is one of the few with the guts to actually follow through on such claims, being one of the darkest and brutal films of the last few years. posts.title: Plastic Bag
posts.excerpt: Quote:This short film by American director Ramin Bahrani (Goodbye Solo) traces the epic, existential journey of a plastic bag (voiced by Werner Herzog) searching for its lost maker, the woman who took it home from the store and eventually discarded it. Along the way, it encounters strange creatures, experiences love in the sky, grieves the …

posts.title: Gaea Girls
posts.excerpt: “This fascinating film follows the physically grueling and mentally exhausting training regimen of several young wanna-be GAEA GIRLS, a group of Japanese women wrestlers. posts.title: Shinjuku Boys
posts.excerpt: A film about love and gender. This documentary is set in the New Marilyn night club in Tokyo, Japan – where the hosts are women who have chosen to live as men.
